1.name: Awareness
1.description: You're becoming aware that mindset can be developed
1.milestone: Catch yourself in a limiting belief and consciously reframe it

2.name: Observer
2.description: Learning to observe thoughts without being controlled by them
2.milestone: 10-day streak of morning journaling or meditation

3.name: Reframer
3.milestone: Successfully navigate a setback using Stoic principles

4.name: Discipline Builder
4.milestone: Complete 30 days of a challenging daily practice

5.name: Resilient
5.milestone: Overcome a significant challenge without losing momentum

6.name: Ownership Taker
6.description: Taking extreme ownership of all outcomes
capabilities: Lead yourself and others through challenges
Take responsibility even when not 'your fault'
6.milestone: Lead a difficult situation to success through ownership

7.name: Antifragile
7.description: Growing stronger through volatility and stress
7.milestone: Deliberately take on a challenge that scares you and grow from it

8.name: Mental Athlete
8.description: Training your mind like an elite athlete trains their body
8.milestone: Perform at your best when it matters most

9.name: Sage
9.description: Deep equanimity regardless of external circumstances
9.milestone: Navigate a major life challenge with grace and growth

10.name: Mindset Master
10.description: Complete mastery over your inner world
10.milestone: Others seek you out for wisdom and perspective

beginner.title: Limiting Belief Detector
beginner.instructions: Write down 5 beliefs about yourself that might be limiting you. For each, ask: Is this absolutely true? What evidence contradicts it? What would change if I didn't believe this?
beginner.success_criteria: 5 limiting beliefs identified with evidence against each

beginner.title: Gratitude Practice Starter
beginner.instructions: Write 3 specific things you're grateful for today. Be specific: not 'family' but 'the conversation with mom that made me laugh.' Do this for 7 consecutive days.
beginner.success_criteria: 7 days of specific gratitude entries (21 total items)

beginner.title: The Comfort Zone Map
beginner.instructions: Draw three circles: Comfort Zone (things you do easily), Growth Zone (things that stretch you), Panic Zone (things that paralyze you). Identify one thing in Growth Zone to tackle this week.
beginner.success_criteria: Completed map with one Growth Zone action committed

intermediate.title: Stoic Morning Premeditatio
intermediate.instructions: Each morning for a week, spend 5 minutes imagining everything that could go wrong today. Then visualize handling each with equanimity. This removes the shock of difficulty and prepares you mentally.
intermediate.success_criteria: 7 days of premeditatio practice with reduced reactivity noted

intermediate.title: Do Something That Sucks
intermediate.instructions: Identify something you've been avoiding because it's uncomfortable (cold shower, difficult conversation, hard workout). Do it. Document how you felt before, during, and after.
intermediate.success_criteria: Completed avoided task with written reflection on the experience

intermediate.title: The 40% Rule Test
intermediate.instructions: During your next challenging task (workout, work project, etc.), when you feel like quitting, recognize this is only 40% of your capacity. Push to 50%, then 60%. Track how far past 'done' you can go.
intermediate.success_criteria: Successfully pushed past initial quitting point and documented the experience

advanced.title: Extreme Ownership Audit
advanced.instructions: Review a recent failure or setback. Instead of identifying external causes, write down every way YOU contributed to the outcome. How could you have anticipated and prevented issues? What will you do differently?
advanced.success_criteria: Honest ownership analysis with actionable changes identified

advanced.title: Fear-Setting Exercise
advanced.instructions: Pick something you want but fear. Write: 1) What's the worst that could happen? 2) How could I prevent each? 3) How could I repair the damage? 4) What's the cost of inaction? 5) What are the benefits of success?
advanced.success_criteria: Complete fear-setting worksheet leading to action decision

advanced.title: Ego Dissolution Practice
advanced.instructions: Identify an area where your ego is fragile (status, being right, looking smart). Deliberately put yourself in a situation where that ego gets challenged. Notice the resistance. Let it go.
advanced.success_criteria: Deliberately challenged ego and processed the experience constructively

cross_module_connections.insight: Physical challenge builds mental resilience - the body and mind train together
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: End every shower with 30 seconds of cold water. Use it as a daily Stoic practice - voluntary discomfort builds inner strength.

cross_module_connections.insight: Rejection immunity is a mindset skill - reframe rejection as information, not personal failure
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Do Rejection Therapy: intentionally get rejected once per day for a week. Notice how the fear decreases.

cross_module_connections.insight: Resistance to hard work is mental, not physical - train your mind to embrace difficulty
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: When you notice resistance to a task, say 'This is where I grow' and start a 25-minute timer.

cross_module_connections.insight: Most financial ceilings are mental - your beliefs about what's possible limit your income
cross_module_connections.combined_exercise: Write down your beliefs about money from childhood. Challenge each one: is this serving you or limiting you?

masters.name: Marcus Aurelius
key_principles: You have power over your mind, not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts.
Waste no more time arguing about what a good man should be. Be one.
Very little is needed to make a happy life; it is all within yourself.
The best revenge is not to be like your enemy.
When you arise in the morning think of what a privilege it is to be alive.
daily_practices: Morning reflection on what's in your control
Evening review of your actions and thoughts
Practice accepting what you cannot change

worked_examples.title: Morning Stoic Practice
worked_examples.scenario: You wake up anxious about a difficult day ahead with meetings you're dreading.
step_by_step: Before rising, visualize the day's challenges
For each challenge, ask: What's in my control? What's not?
For what's not in control: Practice acceptance now, not later
For what's in control: Decide your response in advance
Visualize yourself handling each difficulty with equanimity
Rise with a mind prepared for anything
End with: 'Today I may meet frustrating people. This is normal. My peace is internal.'
worked_examples.outcome: The day's challenges lose their power to disturb you because you've already mentally processed them.

scripts_templates.title: Daily Stoic Journal Template
scripts_templates.context: Use morning and evening for Stoic reflection and growth
scripts_templates.template:
MORNING REFLECTION:

What's in my control today?
- ___
- ___
- ___

What's not in my control?
- ___
- ___

What could go wrong? How will I respond with equanimity?
- If ___, I will ___
- If ___, I will ___

What virtue will I practice today?
- ___

---

EVENING REFLECTION:

What went well today?
- ___

What could I have done better?
- ___

Did I respond to events with virtue?
- ___

What did I learn?
- ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
MORNING:

In my control:
- My preparation for the presentation
- How I respond to feedback
- My attitude throughout

Not in my control:
- Whether they like my proposal
- Technical issues

If the presentation fails, I will: Learn from the feedback and improve
If someone is hostile, I will: Respond with patience, not defensiveness

Virtue today: Courage - speak my truth even if unpopular

---

EVENING:

Went well: Stayed calm during tough questions
Better: Shouldn't have checked email during lunch, lost focus
Virtuous: Yes, spoke honestly even when it was uncomfortable
Learned: My anxiety is always worse than reality

scripts_templates.title: Control Dichotomy Worksheet
scripts_templates.context: Use when stressed or anxious about a situation
scripts_templates.template:
SITUATION: ___

COMPLETELY IN MY CONTROL:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

PARTIALLY IN MY CONTROL:
1. ___ (What part is mine?)
2. ___ (What part is mine?)

NOT IN MY CONTROL AT ALL:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

ACTION PLAN:
Focus my energy on: ___
Accept and release: ___
My peace does not depend on: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
SITUATION: Job interview tomorrow

COMPLETELY IN MY CONTROL:
1. How well I prepare
2. Getting good sleep tonight
3. My attitude walking in

PARTIALLY IN MY CONTROL:
1. My performance (prep is mine, nerves partly aren't)
2. Making a connection (my warmth is mine, their mood isn't)

NOT IN MY CONTROL:
1. Whether they like me
2. What other candidates are like
3. Their internal politics

ACTION PLAN:
Focus on: Preparation and being my authentic self
Accept: The outcome is not up to me
My peace does not depend on: Getting this specific job

books.title: Meditations
books.author: Marcus Aurelius
books.key_takeaway: Private journal of a Roman emperor practicing Stoic philosophy

books.title: The Daily Stoic
books.author: Ryan Holiday
books.key_takeaway: 366 meditations on wisdom, perseverance, and the art of living

podcasts.title: The Daily Stoic Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Daily 5-minute Stoic wisdom for modern life

masters.name: David Goggins
masters.expertise: Mental toughness, extreme accountability, embracing suffering
key_principles: You are in danger of living a life so comfortable and soft that you will die without ever realizing your potential.
The only way to grow is to go to that dark place and get after it.
Most people stop at 40% of their capacity. The brain lies to protect you.
Suffering is a test. How you handle it determines who you become.
Nobody cares what you did yesterday. What are you doing today?
Callus your mind. Embrace the suck.
daily_practices: Do something that sucks every single day
When your mind says stop, do 10 more
Hold yourself accountable with radical honesty

worked_examples.title: The 40% Rule Application
worked_examples.scenario: You're in a workout and everything in you wants to quit.
step_by_step: Recognize the moment: Your brain is telling you to stop
Understand: This is a protection mechanism. You're only at 40%.
Override: Tell yourself 'This is where I grow'
Take one more step, do one more rep, go one more minute
Bank this experience: Each time you override, you callus your mind
The more you do this, the further your 40% point moves
Eventually, discomfort becomes a signal to lean in, not quit
worked_examples.outcome: Your capacity expands dramatically because you learn to operate past the brain's comfort governor.

scripts_templates.title: Accountability Mirror Script
scripts_templates.context: Use daily to have a brutally honest conversation with yourself
scripts_templates.template:
Look in the mirror. Answer honestly:

1. What did I do yesterday that I'm proud of?
   ___

2. What did I avoid or make excuses about?
   ___

3. What lie am I telling myself?
   ___

4. What's the hard thing I know I should do but don't want to?
   ___

5. Am I living up to my potential right now?
   ___

6. What would the best version of me do today?
   ___

NOW: Commit to one hard thing today.
I WILL: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
1. Proud of: Got up early and trained despite not wanting to

2. Avoided: That hard conversation with my partner about finances

3. Lie I'm telling myself: 'I'll start the business next month when things calm down'

4. Hard thing I should do: Make that sales call I've been putting off

5. Living up to potential: No. I'm coasting when I should be pushing.

6. Best version would: Make the calls, have the conversation, stop hiding.

I WILL: Make 10 sales calls before noon. No excuses.

scripts_templates.title: Suffering as Growth Framework
scripts_templates.context: Use when facing a difficult challenge
scripts_templates.template:
THE CHALLENGE: ___

MY NATURAL RESPONSE: (avoidance, complaint, etc.)
___

REFRAME:
- This suffering is: ___
- What I'll gain from embracing it: ___
- Who I'll become by going through it: ___

THE 40% CHECK:
- My brain says I'm done at: ___%
- The truth is I have: ___% more

COMMIT:
I will not quit because: ___

MANTRA:
'___'
scripts_templates.example_filled:
THE CHALLENGE: Training for a marathon with no running background

NATURAL RESPONSE: 'This is too hard, I'm not a runner, maybe next year'

REFRAME:
- This suffering is: An opportunity to prove what I'm capable of
- What I'll gain: Physical capability + mental proof that I can do hard things
- Who I'll become: Someone who follows through on commitments to themselves

THE 40% CHECK:
- My brain says I'm done at: 3 miles in
- The truth is I have: 60% more if I push through

COMMIT:
I will not quit because: The person I want to become runs marathons, and that person starts today.

MANTRA:
'Stay hard.'

books.title: Can't Hurt Me
books.author: David Goggins
books.key_takeaway: Master your mind and defy the odds

books.title: Never Finished
books.author: David Goggins
books.key_takeaway: Unshackle your mind and win the war within

podcasts.title: David Goggins on Joe Rogan
podcasts.key_takeaway: Raw, unfiltered conversation about mental toughness

masters.name: Jocko Willink
key_principles: Discipline equals freedom.
Extreme ownership: There are no bad teams, only bad leaders.
Don't let your ego get in the way of learning.
Prioritize and execute. Focus on the biggest problem first.
Default aggressive. When in doubt, take action.
Check the ego. The moment you think you know everything, you know nothing.
daily_practices: Wake up early. Win the first battle.
Take ownership of every problem in your life
Make discipline your identity, not a chore

worked_examples.title: Applying Extreme Ownership
worked_examples.scenario: A project at work failed and there are many people/factors you could blame.
step_by_step: Resist the urge to blame: Notice any thought that points outward
Ask: What could I have done to prevent this?
Could I have communicated more clearly? Set better expectations?
Could I have anticipated the problem and mitigated it?
Could I have checked in earlier when I sensed issues?
Take 100% ownership publicly: 'This was my fault. Here's what I'm doing differently.'
This earns respect and actually solves problems
worked_examples.outcome: Problems get solved faster when someone owns them. Your team respects you more. You improve faster.

scripts_templates.title: Extreme Ownership Debrief
scripts_templates.context: Use after any setback or failure
scripts_templates.template:
SITUATION: ___

OUTCOME: ___

EASY EXCUSES (things I could blame):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

EXTREME OWNERSHIP (how I contributed):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

WHAT I WILL DO DIFFERENTLY:
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

LESSON I'M TAKING FORWARD:
___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
SITUATION: Product launch missed the deadline by 2 weeks

OUTCOME: Lost market window, CEO unhappy, team demoralized

EASY EXCUSES:
1. The dev team underestimated complexity
2. Marketing changed requirements mid-project
3. We didn't have enough resources

EXTREME OWNERSHIP:
1. I didn't verify the estimate with enough detail
2. I should have frozen requirements earlier
3. I could have raised the resource issue sooner

WHAT I'LL DO DIFFERENTLY:
1. Do technical deep-dives on estimates before committing
2. Set hard requirement freeze dates and enforce them
3. Raise resource concerns immediately, not politely

LESSON: If I see a problem coming, it's my job to fix it, not hope it fixes itself.

scripts_templates.title: Discipline = Freedom Daily Framework
scripts_templates.context: Structure your day around discipline creating freedom
scripts_templates.template:
FREEDOM I WANT: ___

DISCIPLINE REQUIRED:
- Daily: ___
- Weekly: ___
- Monthly: ___

MORNING ROUTINE (non-negotiable):
Wake time: ___
First action: ___
Win before others wake: ___

THE HARD THING I'M AVOIDING:
___

I WILL DO IT BECAUSE:
___

IF I FAIL TO EXECUTE, MY EXCUSE WILL BE:
___

THAT EXCUSE IS: [ ] Valid [ ] BS
scripts_templates.example_filled:
FREEDOM I WANT: Financial independence by 45

DISCIPLINE REQUIRED:
- Daily: 2 hours of focused work on side business before day job
- Weekly: Review metrics, adjust approach
- Monthly: Evaluate strategy, cut what's not working

MORNING ROUTINE:
Wake: 4:30am
First action: Coffee, then immediately to desk
Win: Complete 2 hours of focused work before 7am

HARD THING I'M AVOIDING:
Making sales calls - fear of rejection

I WILL DO IT BECAUSE:
Freedom requires revenue, revenue requires sales

IF I FAIL, MY EXCUSE: 'I was too tired, I needed more sleep'

THAT EXCUSE IS: [x] BS

books.title: Extreme Ownership
books.author: Jocko Willink & Leif Babin
books.key_takeaway: How U.S. Navy SEALs lead and win - applicable to all of life

books.title: Discipline Equals Freedom
books.author: Jocko Willink
books.key_takeaway: Field manual for living a disciplined life

podcasts.title: Jocko Podcast
podcasts.key_takeaway: Discipline, leadership, and mental toughness from a Navy SEAL

masters.name: Carol Dweck
key_principles: In a growth mindset, challenges are exciting rather than threatening.
Becoming is better than being.
The passion for stretching yourself and sticking to it, even when it's not going well, is the hallmark of the growth mindset.
No matter what your ability is, effort is what ignites that ability and turns it into accomplishment.
Just because some people can do something with little or no training doesn't mean others can't do it with training.
Effort is one of those things that gives meaning to life.

worked_examples.title: Converting Fixed to Growth Mindset
worked_examples.scenario: You receive critical feedback and your first reaction is to feel attacked and defensive.
step_by_step: Notice the fixed mindset reaction: 'They don't understand, this is unfair'
Recognize this is a protection mechanism for your ego
Ask: 'What can I learn from this feedback?'
Reframe: 'This feedback shows where I can grow'
Thank the person for their input (this is hard but powerful)
Identify one specific action to improve based on feedback
Your ability isn't fixed - it's being developed
worked_examples.outcome: Feedback becomes fuel for growth rather than an attack on identity. Improvement accelerates.

scripts_templates.title: Growth Mindset Reframe Checklist
scripts_templates.context: Use when you notice fixed mindset thinking
scripts_templates.template:
TRIGGER THOUGHT (fixed mindset):
'___'

CHECK - IS THIS FIXED MINDSET?
[ ] 'I'm not good at this' (vs 'I'm not good at this YET')
[ ] 'I failed' (vs 'I learned what doesn't work')
[ ] 'This is too hard' (vs 'This will take effort and practice')
[ ] 'I'm not a ___ person' (vs 'I haven't developed this skill')
[ ] 'If I have to try hard, I must not be talented'

GROWTH MINDSET REFRAME:
'___'

ACTION THIS ENABLES:
___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
TRIGGER THOUGHT:
'I'm just not a math person'

CHECK:
[x] 'I'm not good at this' - YES, this is fixed mindset

GROWTH MINDSET REFRAME:
'I haven't spent time developing my math skills yet. With practice, I can improve.'

ACTION THIS ENABLES:
Start a daily 15-minute math practice. Focus on progress, not perfection.

books.title: Mindset: The New Psychology of Success
books.author: Carol Dweck
books.key_takeaway: The difference between fixed and growth mindsets and how to change

podcasts.title: Carol Dweck on The Knowledge Project
podcasts.key_takeaway: Deep dive into growth mindset research and application

masters.name: Ryan Holiday
masters.expertise: Stoicism, obstacle as the way, ego management
key_principles: The obstacle is the way. What stands in the way becomes the way.
Ego is the enemy. It's the voice that tells you you're special, you're better.
Stillness is the key. In stillness, we find clarity.
You don't control events, but you control how you respond.
Perception, action, will. That's the stoic formula.
Alive time or dead time. You choose.
daily_practices: Reframe every obstacle as an opportunity
Journal about your perceptions and responses

worked_examples.title: The Obstacle Is The Way Applied
worked_examples.scenario: You lose your job unexpectedly and feel devastated.
step_by_step: PERCEPTION: Reframe the situation. This isn't just a loss - it's an opening.
Ask: What opportunity does this create that didn't exist before?
ACTION: What can I do right now with this new situation?
Could I start the business I've been putting off? Relocate? Pivot careers?
WILL: Accept what happened. Don't waste energy wishing it were different.
Use the obstacle: The job ending might be the push you needed.
Choose alive time: Every day you're learning and moving forward, not bitter and stuck.
worked_examples.outcome: What felt like a disaster becomes a defining positive chapter when you use the obstacle instead of being crushed by it.

scripts_templates.title: Fear-Setting Worksheet (Tim Ferriss/Stoic)
scripts_templates.context: Use when fear is preventing you from taking action
scripts_templates.template:
WHAT I'M AFRAID TO DO:
___

DEFINE THE NIGHTMARE (What's the worst that could realistically happen?):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

PREVENT (What could I do to prevent each?):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

REPAIR (If the worst happened, how could I fix it?):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

COST OF INACTION (What am I losing by not acting?):
- In 6 months: ___
- In 1 year: ___
- In 3 years: ___

BENEFITS OF SUCCESS (What could I gain?):
1. ___
2. ___
3. ___

DECISION: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
WHAT I'M AFRAID TO DO:
Quit my job to start my own business

NIGHTMARE:
1. Run out of money in 6 months
2. Business fails completely
3. Can't get a job again

PREVENT:
1. Save 12 months expenses before quitting
2. Test the business while employed
3. Keep skills current, maintain network

REPAIR:
1. Could get a consulting gig quickly
2. The experience makes me more hireable
3. Network would help me find something

COST OF INACTION:
- 6 months: More time lost, more regret
- 1 year: Still dreaming instead of doing
- 3 years: Will hate myself for not trying

BENEFITS OF SUCCESS:
1. Freedom and control of my time
2. Unlimited income potential
3. Building something meaningful

DECISION: Do it. The cost of inaction exceeds the worst case.

books.title: The Obstacle Is the Way
books.author: Ryan Holiday
books.key_takeaway: The timeless art of turning trials into triumph

books.title: Ego Is the Enemy
books.author: Ryan Holiday
books.key_takeaway: How ego prevents success and how to overcome it

books.title: Stillness Is the Key
books.author: Ryan Holiday
books.key_takeaway: Finding peace and clarity in a noisy world

masters.name: Nassim Taleb
masters.expertise: Antifragility, uncertainty, skin in the game
key_principles: Antifragile: Some things benefit from shocks; they thrive and grow when exposed to volatility.
Wind extinguishes a candle and energizes fire. Be the fire.
The best way to verify that you are alive is by checking if you like variations.
If you want to accelerate someone's death, give them a personal doctor.
Never trust anyone who doesn't have skin in the game.
The three most harmful addictions are heroin, carbohydrates, and a monthly salary.
daily_practices: Expose yourself to small stressors daily
Build redundancy and options in your life

worked_examples.title: Building an Antifragile Life
worked_examples.scenario: You realize your entire life depends on one job, one income source, one set of skills.
step_by_step: Assess fragility: Where would a shock break you?
Build redundancy: Multiple income sources, diverse skills, strong network
Add optionality: Increase options, decrease obligations
Introduce stressors: Voluntary hardship builds resilience
Via negativa: Remove fragilities before adding new things
Embrace variation: Monotony is fragile, variation is antifragile
Skin in the game: Take risks where you bear the consequences
worked_examples.outcome: Each shock makes you stronger because you've built systems that benefit from volatility.

scripts_templates.title: Fragility Audit
scripts_templates.context: Identify and reduce your life's fragilities
scripts_templates.template:
AREA: Career
- Single point of failure: ___
- How to build redundancy: ___

AREA: Income
- Single point of failure: ___
- How to build redundancy: ___

AREA: Health
- Single point of failure: ___
- How to build redundancy: ___

AREA: Relationships
- Single point of failure: ___
- How to build redundancy: ___

BIGGEST FRAGILITY: ___
FIRST ACTION TO REDUCE IT: ___
scripts_templates.example_filled:
AREA: Career
- Single point of failure: Entire income from one employer
- Redundancy: Develop freelance skills, build network, create side income

AREA: Income
- Single point of failure: 100% salary-dependent
- Redundancy: Investment income, side business, emergency fund

AREA: Health
- Single point of failure: Sedentary job, poor diet habits
- Redundancy: Daily movement practice, meal prep, regular checkups

AREA: Relationships
- Single point of failure: No community outside work
- Redundancy: Invest in friendships, join groups, nurture family ties

BIGGEST FRAGILITY: 100% income from job
FIRST ACTION: Start freelancing 5 hours/week to build alternative income

daily_insights: Your thoughts create your reality. Guard them like a fortress.
Comfort is the enemy of progress. Seek discomfort daily.
You're not your emotions. You're the observer of your emotions.
Every setback is a setup for a comeback. Reframe everything.
The quality of your questions determines the quality of your life.
Discipline is choosing what you want most over what you want now.
Your identity drives your behavior. Change who you are, change what you do.
Pain is inevitable. Suffering is optional. It's how you interpret the pain.
Confidence comes from kept promises to yourself. Keep small promises daily.
The obstacle is not in your way. It is the way.
skill_challenges: Do one thing today that scares you.
Take a cold shower. Embrace the discomfort.
Journal for 10 minutes: What am I avoiding and why?
Identify one limiting belief. Write down evidence against it.
Go 24 hours without complaining. Notice how often you want to.
Do something uncomfortable for someone else today.
Meditate for 10 minutes. Just observe your thoughts.
Write down 3 things you're grateful for. Be specific.
Identify one way you made an excuse today. Take ownership instead.
Say no to one thing you'd normally say yes to. Protect your priorities.
